body: Orthodoxy is still Christianity as it was taught by the Apostles
body_html: Orthodoxy is still Christianity as it was taught by the Apostles

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body: Yeah something tells me that rewrapping the entire gospel to be palatable to the waning and petty ideological interests of nihilists who hate your religion anyway isn't exactly going to pay dividends.

body: I wasn't converted by a church, but that aside: I don't deny that religious ideas ought to be taught through different means in different contexts, but bowing out of long-held traditions, practices and principles to pander to a crowd who'd never convert anyway is just self-destructive for the religion. For example, a Marxist reading of The Bible could be attempted, but would do nobody any good, and it would be neither marxist, nor Christian. We'd do well as Christians to maintain a conviction and sureness of belief that exists beyond mere ideology.
body_html: I wasn't converted by a church, but that aside: I don't deny that religious ideas ought to be taught through different means in different contexts, but bowing out of long-held traditions, practices and principles to pander to a crowd who'd never convert anyway is just self-destructive for the religion. For example, a Marxist reading of The Bible could be attempted, but would do nobody any good, and it would be neither marxist, nor Christian. We'd do well as Christians to maintain a conviction and sureness of belief that exists beyond mere ideology.
